newsitem.title: JAPAN: Poll points to clear LDP majority in Japan election.
newsitem.headline: Poll points to clear LDP majority in Japan election.

text.p: Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto's Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) is likely to win a clear parliamentary majority in Japan's general election on Sunday, a newspaper survey released on Tuesday found.
A nationwide poll of 150,000 eligible voters conducted by the business daily Nihon Keizai Shimbun at the weekend showed the LDP would win a simple majority of 251 seats in the 500-seat chamber.
Such a result would return the party to the position of sole power it held for nearly four decades until 1993.
The party held 211 seats in the Lower House when it was dissolved earlier this month. The LDP shared power in the outgoing coalition.
The survey found that Japan's main opposition group, Shinshinto (the New Frontier Party), would struggle to maintain its level of 160 seats.
The Democratic Party, formed last month by defectors from the two smaller parties that were in the ruling coalition with the LDP, would win 52 seats, it said.
Most analysts had predicted that no one party would win a clear majority and that a new coalition would have to be formed.

The polls will be the first to be held under a new electoral system in which the 300 members of the powerful Lower House will be chosen in single-seat constituencies, while 200 will be elected through proportional representation.
